Order Bars in ggplot2 bar graph

473: <p>You could also have a look at the <a href="http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/system.runtime.serialization.json.datacontractjsonserializer.aspx" rel="noreferrer">DataContractJsonSerializer</a></p>
474:
<p><code>ArrayList</code> is randomly accessible, while <code>LinkedList</code> is really cheap to expand and remove elements from. For most cases, <code>ArrayList</code> is fine.</p>

<p>Unless you've created large lists and measured a bottleneck, you'll probably never need to worry about the difference.</p>

<p>If your code has <code>add(0)</code> and <code>remove(0)</code>, use a <code>LinkedList</code> and it's prettier <code>addFirst()</code> and <code>removeFirst()</code> methods. Otherwise, use <code>ArrayList</code>.</p>

<p>And of course, <a href="https://github.com/google/guava" rel="noreferrer">Guava</a>'s <a href="https://google.github.io/guava/releases/21.0/api/docs/com/google/common/collect/ImmutableList.html" rel="noreferrer">ImmutableList</a> is your best friend.</p>

<p>I usually use one over the other based on the time complexities of the operations that I'd perform on that particular List.                                                                  </p>

<pre class="lang-java s-code-block"><code class="hljs language-java">|---------------------|---------------------|--------------------|------------|
|      Operation      |     ArrayList       |     LinkedList     |   Winner   |
|---------------------|---------------------|--------------------|------------|
|     get(index)      |       O(<span class="hljs-number">1</span>)          |         O(n)       | ArrayList  |
|                     |                     |  n/<span class="hljs-number">4</span> steps in avg  |            |
|---------------------|---------------------|--------------------|------------|
|      add(E)         |       O(<span class="hljs-number">1</span>)          |         O(<span class="hljs-number">1</span>)       | LinkedList |
|                     |---------------------|--------------------|            |
|                     | O(n) in worst <span class="hljs-keyword">case</span>  |                    |            |
|---------------------|---------------------|--------------------|------------|
|    add(index, E)    |       O(n)          |         O(n)       | LinkedList |
|                     |     n/<span class="hljs-number">2</span> steps       |      n/<span class="hljs-number">4</span> steps     |            |
|                     |---------------------|--------------------|            |
|                     |                     |  O(<span class="hljs-number">1</span>) <span class="hljs-type">if</span> <span class="hljs-variable">index</span> <span class="hljs-operator">=</span> <span class="hljs-number">0</span> |            |
|---------------------|---------------------|--------------------|------------|
|  remove(index, E)   |       O(n)          |         O(n)       | LinkedList |
|                     |---------------------|--------------------|            |
|                     |     n/<span class="hljs-number">2</span> steps       |      n/<span class="hljs-number">4</span> steps     |            |
|---------------------|---------------------|--------------------|------------|
|  Iterator.remove()  |       O(n)          |         O(<span class="hljs-number">1</span>)       | LinkedList |
|  ListIterator.add() |                     |                    |            |
|---------------------|---------------------|--------------------|------------|


|--------------------------------------|-----------------------------------|
|              ArrayList               |            LinkedList             |
|--------------------------------------|-----------------------------------|
|     Allows fast read access          |   Retrieving element takes <span class="hljs-title function_">O</span><span class="hljs-params">(n)</span>   |
|--------------------------------------|-----------------------------------|
|   Adding an element require shifting | o(<span class="hljs-number">1</span>) [but traversing takes time]  |
|       all the later elements         |                                   |
|--------------------------------------|-----------------------------------|
|   To add more elements than capacity |
|    <span class="hljs-keyword">new</span> <span class="hljs-title class_">array</span> need to be allocated    |
|--------------------------------------|
</code></pre>

<p>I know this is an old post, but I honestly can't believe nobody mentioned that <code>LinkedList</code> implements <code>Deque</code>.  Just look at the methods in <code>Deque</code> (and <code>Queue</code>); if you want a fair comparison, try running <code>LinkedList</code> against <code>ArrayDeque</code> and do a feature-for-feature comparison. </p>

<p>In addition to the other good arguments above, you should notice <code>ArrayList</code> implements <code>RandomAccess</code> interface, while <code>LinkedList</code> implements <code>Queue</code>.</p>

<p>So, somehow they address slightly different problems, with difference of efficiency and behavior (see their list of methods).</p>
<p>See <a href="http://download.oracle.com/javase/tutorial/collections/implementations/list.html" rel="noreferrer">the Java Tutorials - List Implementations</a>.</p>

<p>An array list is essentially an array with methods to add items etc. (and you should use a generic list instead). It is a collection of items which can be accessed through an indexer  (for example [0]). It implies a progression from one item to the next.</p>

<p>A linked list specifies a progression from one item to the next (Item a -&gt; item b).  You can get the same effect with an array list, but a linked list absolutely says what item is supposed to follow the previous one. </p>

<p>An important feature of a linked list (which I didn't read in another answer) is the concatenation of two lists. With an array this is O(n) (+ overhead of some reallocations) with a linked list this is only O(1) or O(2) ;-)</p>

<p><strong>Important</strong>: For Java its <code>LinkedList</code> this is not true! See <a href="https://stackoverflow.com/q/2494031/587642">Is there a fast concat method for linked list in Java?</a></p>

<pre class="lang-js s-code-block"><code class="hljs language-javascript"><span class="hljs-keyword">var</span> randomnumber = <span class="hljs-title class_">Math</span>.<span class="hljs-title function_">floor</span>(<span class="hljs-title class_">Math</span>.<span class="hljs-title function_">random</span>() * (maximum - minimum + <span class="hljs-number">1</span>)) + minimum;
</code></pre>
